original_title: Sri Lanka to set maximum retail price for fuel after new players: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is planning to set a maximum retail price for fuel in the future, with distributers free to sell below the price, State Minister for Energy D V Chanaka said.
Sri Lanka has opened fuel distribution to several companies including China’s Sinopec which will is expected to bring its first shipment early next month.
“The ministry will set a maximum retail price in the future,” Minister Chanaka told reporters, at the President’s media office.
“Companies can sell at the price of their choice, subject to the maximum limit. There will be competition. If one company reduces the price, and others follow, there will be a big benefit.”
It is not clear why prices cannot be completely de-controlled.
Sri Lanka’s fuel prices are high partly due to procurement inefficiencies and risk premiums charged from Ceylon Petroleum Corporation after the latest currency crisis.
For many years Lanka IOC has reported higher profits, despite the CPC importing crude oil at lower taxes. (Colombo/July24/2023)
